awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Online Game to Assess and Improve Behavioral Readiness and Social Emotional Skills  for Students in Kindergarten and First Grades
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project aims to create and test a game-based intelligent tutoring system that both assesses and improves the behavioral readiness and social emotional skills of Kindergarten and 1st grade students. Research has shown that early intervention for children with social skill deficiencies is critical for success in the classroom and success in life. Children from vulnerable, underserved social niches are particularly likely to be 'less ready' for school, including those who experience poverty, family instability, and trauma, each of which disproportionately impact children from racial and ethnic minority groups. The game being developed by this project empowers educators to provide that much needed social emotional learning support for their young students. First, it provides an affordable, feasible, and scaleable means for identifying the social emotional needs of young students as they transition to formal schooling. Second, it enables educators to quickly translate this formative assessment data into personalized, digital intervention that can be applied with K1 students on a much broader scale than is possible with traditional, in-person services. And lastly, because this innovation is game-based and fun, students are more likely to fully engage and fully benefit from the embedded instruction. 


This project will advance understanding of how an Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) can be used effectively to help educators provide social emotional instruction to all students. Within academic domains such as science and mathematics, many successful ITS implementations have employed learning models where answers to problems and the knowledge being evaluated can be easily represented. However, traditional ITS techniques have not been as effective in domains like social emotional learning, where the connection between what a student does and what the student knows is less well-defined. This project will develop several significant innovations for ITS that apply to social and emotional learning, but may also be useful in other, less well-defined learning domains. These innovations are represented by our adaptive Student Model and Tutorial Manager which collectively enhance student learning via personalization, pacing, and engagement. As more student data is collected, the student model will become increasingly accurate, leading to more intelligent choices from the tutorial manager to better enhance the social tutoring of our innovation and thereby, student learning. In addition to addressing significant societal and market needs, research findings from this SBIR will be published to more broadly inform the efforts of the ITS community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report: NSF SBIR Phase II Award #1853055: Online Game to Assess and Improve Behavioral Readiness and Social Emotional Skills for Students in Kindergarten and First Grade

With Phase II SBIR award funding from the National Science Foundation, Personalized Learning Games created a web-based game, called Zoo Academy?, that teaches social emotional skills to 5-6 year old children. Our primary goal was to create a system that could be used to improve behavioral readiness for students entering the school system in either Kindergarten or first grade.

During the award period, we completed development of Zoo Academy? and made it available for purchase by educators, clinicians, schools, and districts. This work consisted of 18 game scenes with over 160 pages of scripts, art for over 50 characters, and over 2000 lines of dialog.

Broader Impacts and Outcomes

Every year, 4.3 million children across the United States start Kindergarten. Unfortunately, 50% of these children fail to make a smooth transition and nearly 20% experience serious difficulties (Pianta & Kraft-Sayre, 2003). A 2016 study of 9,000 students in Baltimore City Schools exemplifies these interrelations where by fourth grade, the Baltimore students identified as ?not ready? in Kindergarten were: 

  • Seven times more likely to have been suspended or expelled

  • 80% more likely to be in a special education program

  • 80% more likely to have been retained

As these challenges underscore a compelling need, our goal was to make social emotional learning fun, feasible, and affordable to improve outcomes for these early learners. 

To date, the reception to the commercial version of Zoo Academy has been robust. Over 25,000 educators, representing over 10,000 schools have signed up for a trial account. In turn, over 50,000 students have used Zoo Academy. And from these trials, 20% of students are now using the program with a paid license.

Educators report that students are deeply engaged in Zoo Academy and often request additional time to use the program beyond the time they are allocated in class. This is exactly what we had hoped for given that increasing the time spent using the intervention leads to improved student outcomes (based on new research described below).

It is important to note that all of the commercial use of Zoo Academy thus far has been during the COVID-19 pandemic. With Zoo Academy being 100% digital, educators have been able to use the program remotely when schools were closed and now in person. 

In addition, with all of the anxiety and mental health challenges associated with the pandemic, students using Zoo Academy have completed over 175,000 emotion check-ins. This data has helped educators better understand and address students that need additional support on any given day. 

While  new research on Zoo Academy has been modest, we received extremely positive results from an RCT study of another of our SEL programs, Adventures Aboard the SS GRIN. This study confirmed that our game-based approach to social emotional learning effectively improves social emotional learning and outcomes for students in the real world. 

Based on this progress, we are confident that Zoo Academy will have a large and lasting social impact on students early in their educational journey, and the program will be a cornerstone in the success of our company.

 


Last Modified: 03/28/2022
Modified by: James M Thomas

    Personalized Learning Games

    James M Thomas
